data.title: MiMedx Group (MDXG) Revenue Jump To US$118.1 Million Tests Slow Growth Narrative
data.description:
MiMedx Group (MDXG) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of about US$118.1 million and basic EPS of roughly US$0.10, while trailing twelve month figures sit at around US$418.6 million of revenue and US$0.33 of basic EPS. Over the past few quarters, the company has seen revenue move from US$84.1 million in Q3 2024 to US$92.9 million in Q4 2024 and then to US$118.1 million in Q4 2025, with quarterly basic EPS ranging from about US$0.05 to US$0.11 across that stretch. With a trailing net profit margin of 11.6%, the latest earnings print gives investors a clear view of a business that is currently generating consistent profits.

See our full analysis for MiMedx Group.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings story lines up against the widely followed narratives around MiMedx's growth, profitability, and longer term potential.

See what the community is saying about MiMedx Group

TTM profit of US$48.6 million supports 11.6% margin story

  • Over the last twelve months to Q4 2025, MiMedx generated about US$418.6 million of revenue and US$48.6 million of net income, which lines up with the 11.6% net margin mentioned earlier and shows profit has stayed in the low double digits.
  • Analysts' consensus view links this kind of profitability to long term earnings potential, yet the small move in net margin from about 12% to 11.6% shows that while the business is currently earning solid profits, it is not breaking away from margin pressure as clearly as the consensus narrative suggests.

Quarterly EPS range of US$0.05 to US$0.11 keeps growth grounded

  • Across the last six reported quarters, basic EPS has sat in a fairly tight band between roughly US$0.05 and US$0.11 per share, with Q4 2025 at about US$0.10 and trailing twelve month EPS at about US$0.33, which shows earnings are positive but not moving in a straight line.
  • Supporters in the bullish camp point to strong clinical positioning and product expansion as drivers of long term earnings, yet the step up and down in quarterly EPS within this US$0.05 to US$0.11 range reminds you that even with those tailwinds, the earnings path has been bumpy rather than smooth so far.
    • The bullish narrative highlights diversified product expansion and operational efficiencies as reasons to expect stronger earnings over time, while the actual EPS path from about US$0.05 in Q1 2025 to roughly US$0.11 in Q3 2025 and US$0.10 in Q4 2025 shows that cost and revenue timing still matter a lot quarter to quarter.
    • Backers also argue that investments in clinical trials and new launches can support margin improvement, but with trailing twelve month net income of around US$48.6 million on US$418.6 million of revenue, the current earnings base is still modest compared with the growth ambitions in that bullish story.

Bulls argue there is more to this EPS trend than the last few quarters show, and if you want to see how they frame the upside case in detail you can check out üêÇ MiMedx Group Bull Case

P/E of 15.1x vs slower 3.8% revenue forecast

  • MiMedx is reported on a trailing P/E of 15.1x compared with a DCF fair value of US$14.55 per share and a current share price of US$4.94, while revenue growth is projected at about 3.8% per year, which is slower than the 10.4% figure cited for the broader US market.
  • Critics in the bearish narrative focus on reimbursement changes and a concentrated product set as reasons that growth could be pressured, and the combination of a 3.8% revenue growth forecast and a net margin close to 11.6% gives those worries some footing even though the current P/E is lower than the 23x industry average.
    • The bearish view highlights potential Medicare reforms and possible market contraction as threats to both volumes and margins, and the already slower projected top line growth compared with the broader market shows why those policy shifts matter for future revenue lines.
    • Concerns about reliance on a limited placental allograft portfolio also tie back to the 11.6% net margin, because if reimbursement or competing products affect that core segment, the current earnings level of roughly US$48.6 million on US$418.6 million of sales could be sensitive to any shock in that main business.

Skeptics watching that 15.1x P/E against slower projected growth may want to see how a more cautious case is laid out in full through üêª MiMedx Group Bear Case

data.title: BlueNord (OB:BNOR) Q4 Profitability Surge Tests Bearish Earnings Decline Narrative
data.description:
BlueNord (OB:BNOR) closed out FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$362 million and basic EPS of US$2.21, while trailing 12 month figures showed revenue of US$1.04 billion and EPS of US$3.74. Over the past few quarters, revenue has moved from US$192.9 million in Q4 2024 to US$171.1 million in Q1 2025, US$260.2 million in Q2, US$246 million in Q3, and then US$362 million in Q4, with quarterly EPS shifting from a loss of US$2.86 to profits between US$0.19 and US$2.21. With the company now profitable on a trailing basis, the latest numbers put the focus on how durable those margins look against softer forward forecasts and financing risks.

See our full analysis for BlueNord.

With the headline figures on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up with the key narratives around BlueNord, and where the numbers start to challenge those stories.

See what the community is saying about BlueNord

Advertisement

TTM profit of US$97.5 million changes the story

  • On a trailing basis BlueNord earned US$97.5 million of net income and US$3.74 in EPS on US$1.04b of revenue, compared with a trailing loss of US$70.8 million a year earlier on US$702.3 million of revenue.
  • Bulls highlight that this move into profitability, alongside reported 5 year earnings growth of 14.5% per year, fits their view that Tyra ramp up and lower lifting costs can support long duration cash generation, although forecasts of roughly 2.5% annual earnings declines over the next three years pull in the opposite direction.

Q4 margin jump vs weaker forward forecasts

  • In Q4 2025 BlueNord generated US$55.3 million of net income on US$362 million of revenue, after earlier 2025 quarters with net income between US$4.9 million and US$18.6 million on revenue between US$171.1 million and US$260.2 million, while forecasts point to about 2.5% annual earnings declines and 0.4% annual revenue declines over the next three years.
  • Bears argue that expected revenue growth of 6.7% per year and margins rising to 8% in their narrative still sit against these softer aggregate forecasts and the company‚Äôs flagged issue that interest payments are not well covered by earnings, so they focus on the risk that periods like Q4 are hard to repeat consistently when production bottlenecks or higher operating costs show up.

Bears warn that if you are relying on strong quarters like Q4 to continue while forecasts and interest coverage look tougher, it is worth reading the full cautious case in üêª BlueNord Bear Case

P/E of 13.3x and a huge DCF gap

  • With the shares at NOK502 and trailing EPS at US$3.74, the data shows a P/E of 13.3x versus a European Oil & Gas average of 15.4x. A DCF fair value of NOK4,205.12 is very large compared with the current price and also sits well above the single analyst target level of NOK567.60 in the dataset.
  • Supporters of the bullish view point to that gap to the DCF fair value and to the idea of revenue growing 13.3% per year with margins improving to 17.8%. The same dataset flags that earnings are forecast to decline about 2.5% per year instead, so the current 13.3x multiple and weaker interest coverage give you a useful check on how much of the optimistic scenario is already being tested by actual reported numbers.

data.title: What Daiwa House Industry (TSE:1925)'s New U.S. Holding Structure and Higher Dividend Guidance Means For Shareholders

data.title: Northland Power Q4 Profitability Contrasts With Trailing Losses And Tests Bullish Earnings Narratives
data.description:
Advertisement

Northland Power FY 2025 earnings snapshot

Northland Power (TSX:NPI) closed out FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of C$725.3 million and basic EPS of C$0.95, while its trailing 12 month profile still reflects a loss with EPS at C$0.62 and net income of C$163.2 million. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from C$582.3 million in Q4 2024 to C$725.3 million in Q4 2025, alongside EPS shifting from C$0.49 to C$0.95 over the same period. This sets up an earnings picture where recent quarterly profitability contrasts with a loss making trailing 12 month base. For investors, the mix of positive Q4 earnings on top of loss making full year figures keeps the spotlight firmly on how margins hold up from here.

See our full analysis for Northland Power.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up against the key narratives around Northland Power's profitability, growth potential, and risk profile that investors have been talking about.

See what the community is saying about Northland Power

Loss making over C$160 million on a 12 month view

  • On a trailing 12 month basis to Q4 2025, Northland Power recorded total revenue of about C$2.4b and a net loss of C$163.2 million, which contrasts with Q4 alone showing net income of C$249.5 million.
  • What stands out for the bearish narrative is that this 12 month loss comes after multiple loss making quarters, including Q3 2025 net loss of C$414.0 million and Q2 2025 net loss of C$64.1 million. Critics argue this keeps cash flow and long term earnings visibility under pressure even as individual quarters like Q4 look strong.
    • Bears also point to weak coverage of interest costs and dividends, with earnings currently not covering a 3.32% dividend yield or interest expense. This ties directly into concerns about elevated debt and C$9b already spent plus C$6b still expected on Baltic Power and Hai Long.
    • At the same time, consensus commentary about step changes in EBITDA from new offshore wind and storage projects is hard to reconcile with the recent pattern of trailing losses, including a trailing loss of C$285.9 million just one quarter earlier in Q3 2025.
Northland‚Äôs recent loss pattern and debt funded build out give cautious investors plenty to question in the more optimistic forecasts of future earnings power. üêª Northland Power Bear Case

Slow 1.7% revenue growth versus wider market

  • Over the past 12 months, revenue has grown by about 1.7% per year compared to a 6.1% per year forecast for the Canadian market, even though quarterly revenue moved from C$582.3 million in Q4 2024 to C$725.3 million in Q4 2025.
  • Analysts' bullish case leans heavily on new projects like Hai Long and Baltic Power and on grid scale storage, arguing that these additions can lift margins from about 2.3% loss making levels today toward 16.5% over three years. However, the current modest 1.7% revenue growth rate and history of wind resource issues and curtailments in places like the German offshore assets show how sensitive actual revenue can be to weather and power price conditions.
    • On the supportive side for bulls, Q4 2025 revenue of C$725.3 million and net income of C$249.5 million follow Q4 2024 revenue of C$582.3 million and net income of C$126.8 million, which aligns with the view that new assets and better contract mix can improve earnings in stronger periods.
    • Against that, the same 12 month data set still shows the business unprofitable and dropping several onshore and battery projects in Ontario, Alberta, and New York. This pushes back on the idea that growth from here is straightforward or that all pipeline projects will translate into higher revenue.
For investors weighing that slower 1.7% revenue growth against the big project pipeline, it helps to see how others frame the trade off between new capacity, weather risk, and contract quality. üêÇ Northland Power Bull Case

Valuation sits below both DCF fair value and peers

  • At a current share price of C$21.69, Northland Power trades below the DCF fair value of about C$23.78 and at a P/S of 2.3x, compared with 3.0x for the broader North American renewable energy industry and 3.5x for peers.
  • Consensus narrative suggests that expansion into grid scale storage and offshore wind and the use of long term, inflation linked contracts could justify these lower multiples over time. Yet the combination of a trailing loss of C$163.2 million and interest expenses that are not well covered by earnings means the current discount can also be read as the market pricing in balance sheet risk and a reliance on analyst forecasts that expect earnings of C$454.1 million by around 2028.
    • The spread between the share price of C$21.69 and DCF fair value of C$23.78, plus a forecast earnings growth rate of about 40% per year and an analyst target of C$22.42, are the main numbers backing the view that the shares are not expensive

Some bulls argue this mix of US$2.2b in revenue and heavy current losses could be the setup for a sharp earnings swing if their margin expectations play out, but they are starting from a very loss heavy year.

üêÇ Chime Financial Bull Case

Quarterly Profit Swings Highlight Execution Risk

  • Within FY 2025, net income ranged from a profit of US$12.9 million in Q1 to a loss of US$923.4 million in Q2, with Q3 and Q4 losses of US$54.7 million and US$44.8 million, so profitability has moved around a lot within a single year.

    • The very large loss in Q2 2025, alongside much smaller losses in Q3 and Q4, supports the cautious narrative that scaling products like MyPay and instant loans could expose Chime to earnings volatility if credit costs or operating expenses spike again.
    • Even with revenue between US$518.7 million and US$596.4 million across the 2025 quarters, the shift from a small profit in Q1 to sizable losses later in the year gives skeptics concrete data to reference when they argue that earnings quality is still unproven.

Bonheur (OB:BONHR) FY 2025 earnings snapshot

Bonheur (OB:BONHR) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of NOK2.9b and basic EPS of NOK3, rounding out a trailing twelve month EPS of NOK33.4 and net income of NOK1.4b. Trailing twelve month EPS has tracked between NOK21.81 and NOK33.4 over the last six reported periods.   • Over the last twelve months, Bonheur generated NOK12.5b of revenue and NOK1.4b of net income, giving an 11.4% net margin compared with 8.2% a year earlier, alongside 24.8% earnings growth.
  • What stands out for the bullish view is that this higher margin coincides with a period when quarterly revenue has been fairly steady between NOK2.9b and NOK3.6b. That supports the idea that profitability, not just top line, is doing more of the work.

Approach 1: Daiichi Sankyo Company Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company might be worth by projecting its future cash flows and then discounting those back to today to get a single present value figure.

For Daiichi Sankyo Company, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve month free cash flow is a loss of ¬•46.2b, so the valuation leans heavily on expected improvements in future cash generation rather than recent cash flow alone.

Putting all of those cash flows together, the DCF model suggests an estimated intrinsic value of about ¬•5,305 per share, compared with the recent share price of ¬•3,051. That gap implies the stock screens as around 42.5% undervalued on this measure alone.

Approach 2: Daiichi Sankyo Company Price vs Earnings (P/E)

For a profitable business, the P/E ratio is a useful shorthand for how much investors are paying for each unit of earnings. This makes it a practical way to compare companies of different sizes within the same sector.

What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E depends a lot on expectations and risk. Higher expected earnings growth or perceived stability can support a higher P/E, while lower growth or higher risk usually point to a lower, more cautious P/E range.

Margins Under Pressure At 12.8%

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model projects a company‚Äôs future cash flows and then discounts them back to today‚Äôs value. The goal is to estimate what the business might be worth per share at present.

Basic EPS moved from a ‚Ç¨6.01 loss to a ‚Ç¨28.88 loss over FY 2024 and then to a ‚Ç¨4.63 loss in the latest period, leaving the story centered on pressure at the earnings line and the strain that puts on margins.

See our full analysis for Altareit.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings print lines up with the widely held narratives around Altareit‚Äôs trajectory, and where the data may support or challenge those views.

Losses Persist At Net Income Level

  • Altareit reported net income excluding extra items of an ‚Ç¨8.1 million loss in the first half of FY 2025, compared with losses of ‚Ç¨10.5 million in the first half of FY 2024 and ‚Ç¨50.5 million in the second half of FY 2024, while trailing 12 month net income stands at a ‚Ç¨67.1 million loss.
  • Critics highlight that the company is unprofitable, with net losses having grown at about 48.3% per year over five years, and the current figures back up that concern.
    • The trailing 12 month net income loss of ‚Ç¨67.1 million sits well above the latest half year loss of ‚Ç¨8.1 million, which points to pressure persisting beyond a single reporting period.
    • With no positive EPS in any of the reported halves and a trailing 12 month basic EPS of a ‚Ç¨38.38 loss, the bearish focus on weak profitability is strongly supported by the numbers provided.

Revenue Scale Versus Ongoing Losses

  • On a trailing 12 month basis to the second half of FY 2025, Altareit generated ‚Ç¨1.98b of revenue but still recorded a ‚Ç¨67.1 million net income loss, highlighting that sizeable revenue has not translated into positive bottom line results in this dataset.
  • Bears argue that this disconnect between revenue and earnings points to structural pressure, and the trailing figures give them plenty to point to.
    • Across the three trailing 12 month snapshots provided, revenue moves from ‚Ç¨2.61b to ‚Ç¨2.34b and then to ‚Ç¨1.98b, while net income stays in loss territory between ‚Ç¨58.6 million and ‚Ç¨67.1 million, which does not suggest a clear path to profitability in these numbers.
    • With no forward forecasts in the input and repeated losses alongside multi billion euro revenue, the cautious narrative around business efficiency is reinforced by the available data.

Valuation Multiples Face Profitability Risk

  • Altareit trades on a P/S of 0.5x, above the stated peer average of 0.4x but well below the European Real Estate industry average of 4.7x, while the company remains loss making on a trailing 12 month basis.
  • What stands out for bearish investors is that even this relatively low P/S comes with several flagged financial risks, which keeps the focus on balance sheet strength and cash flow rather than headline multiples alone.
    • The analysis notes that operating cash flow does not adequately cover debt, so the company is carrying debt risk at the same time as posting a ‚Ç¨67.1 million net income loss over the latest trailing 12 month period.
    • With earnings described as having declined around 48.3% per year over five years, bears see the current 0.5x P/S as not automatically cheap when weighed against sustained losses and weak cash coverage of debt.

At a share price of A$4.05, TPG Telecom has a 1 day share price return of 3.58%, adding to a 90 day share price return of 8.00% and a 1 year total shareholder return of 30.67%. This pattern suggests momentum has been building rather than fading.

If this shift toward embedded software partnerships has your attention, it could be a good moment to broaden your watchlist with our 2 top founder-led companies as another source of potential ideas.

With TPG trading close to analyst targets and carrying an intrinsic value premium, yet showing strong recent share price momentum, should you see room for mispricing here or assume the market is already pricing in future growth?

Most Popular Narrative: 5.4% Undervalued

With TPG Telecom's most followed narrative pointing to a fair value of A$4.28 against a last close of A$4.05, the story hinges on what its 5G and digital investments could mean for future cash generation and margins.

Material network and IT investment cycles including 5G rollout, Huawei equipment replacement, and brand system overhauls are now largely complete, setting up a multi-year period of structurally lower capex. This will directly boost free cash flow conversion and capital returns, while also enabling cost-outs ($100m targeted by 2029) to flow through to net profit.

Result: Fair Value of A$4.28 (UNDERVALUED)

However, there is still real execution risk, especially if intense mobile and broadband competition crimps margins or complex IT consolidation and cyber issues disrupt customer service.

While the popular narrative sees TPG Telecom as 5.4% undervalued with a fair value of A$4.28, our DCF model points the other way. On future cash flows, TPG is estimated at A$3.50, below the current A$4.05 share price. This frames the stock as overvalued by this method.
